title: How Google is supporting the circular economy
summary: The article discusses Google's efforts towards achieving a circular economy, emphasizing waste reduction, resource reuse, and eco-friendly product design, across its data centers, campuses, and product line.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article describes Google's initiatives towards a circular economy, focusing on waste reduction, resource reuse, and sustainability, thus contributing to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE - The article highlights Google's implementation of new strategies and processes, such as circularity programmes at data centres, introducing a circular approach to business operations.
green_product: TRUE - The article details Google's commitment to sustainable product design, using recycled materials, promoting circular design, and aiming for zero waste in product and hardware design.
green_process: TRUE - The article showcases Google's utilization of green processes, including repairing components, refurbishing equipment, and recycling materials to reduce waste and drive sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 511210 - Software Publishers, 541512 - Computer Systems Design Services, 541990 - All Other Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services, 518210 - Data Processing, Hosting, and Related Services
greenwashing: FALSE - The article illustrates Google's tangible efforts and achievements in implementing sustainable practices, recycling, and waste reduction, without misleading claims or information.

title: Aquafil – Helping Define the Circular Business Model of the Future
summary: Aquafil SpA advocates for a shift towards circular business models to drive a circular economy in interior design and architecture, emphasizing product-as-a-service models, product use extension, and take-back programs to reduce resource extraction and waste buildup.
green_innovation: TRUE. The article discusses the transition to circular business models emphasizing the reduction of resource extraction and waste buildup, aligning with the principles of green innovation.
business_innovation: TRUE. The article mentions the adoption of innovative business models in design and architecture, such as product-as-a-service, product use extension, and take-back programs, which differ significantly from traditional business processes.
green_product: TRUE. The article discusses the development and adoption of circular business models focusing on products that are designed, manufactured, and used in a way that reduces environmental impact throughout their life cycles.
green_process: TRUE. The article emphasizes the importance of implementing green processes in businesses, such as product use extension and take-back programs, to minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325223 - Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing, 326150 - Urethane and Other Foam Product (except Polystyrene) Manufacturing, 327910 - Abrasive Product Manufacturing, 541310 - Architectural Services
greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not exhibit signs of greenwashing as it focuses on genuine efforts towards sustainability and circular economy practices.

green_process: TRUE. The article describes the methods used to ensure the tiny house prototype's construction minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability through the use of renewable and recyclable materials.

title: Target talks turning old car seats into adorable storage crates — and the future of its Target Zero initiative
summary: Target's sustainability strategy includes initiatives like recycling car seats, creating circular products, and reducing single-use packaging to promote a more sustainable future.
